replies.text:
leo exactly. I don't remember anyone batting an eye for movies like Wonder Woman, Predator, Terminator, Tomb Raider, Widows, etc. 

I honestly think most people don't care if the lead character is female, black, white, gay, trans, etc. so long as 
1) The story and character are written well
2) The SJW agenda isn't being shoved down our throat

replies.text: I think most people don't care. They just want a good movie. It's the feminists who really make a big deal about gender. They need sexism to be a rampant problem. Wonder Woman came out without the feminist fanfare, and no one complained about gender.

replies.text: KainaX122 well that‚Äôs good on you but it doesn‚Äôt negate the pricks who do. I like to think most people can get past that stuff too but the truth is there‚Äôs a lot of people on both sides.

replies.author: @KainaX122
replies.text:
Chris Collins I haven't read the book either, though I do want to either watch the movie or read the book. 

I'm just personally not tied to the idea that a character HAS to be a particular race mostly because that's a very arbitrary trait

Someone once asked me what I'd think if they decided to make a black Superman. Granted, I think it'd be a bit odd given all the portrayals of Superman as white but the only real problem I would have if is they didn't give a reasonable explanation for WHY he was black in this portrayal -- something even as simple as "Not everyone on Krypton was white. Their species was made up of several different races like ours on Earth."

replies.author: @KainaX122
replies.text:
Hey! Arnold Lama I'm not trying to negate the people who do -- I don't like them either. 

I'm addressing your dismissal that I actually DO care what race a character is

author: @trevor5834
text: Captain Marvel was just a meh movie. It wasn't the worst Marvel movie, but not the best either. I feel like a better writer could have made the movie 1000x better. Carol Danvers has no dynamic character arc, which could work if the movie was written to use a flat character arc (much like how shonen character arcs are written), but the surrounding story beats heavily suggest that some sort of character progression should be taking place and none ever happens. It felt disjointed for beats to go by and you'd expect change of some sort, especially in regards to Carol apparently being too emotional as the movie stated that it was a problem 3 times before the climax (if I remember correctly), but nothing ever comes about. Lazy writing made a potential 8 or 9/10 a 5/10.

author: @justaguy1458
text:
I had to wipe my phone off... dripping with sarcasm following your intro.

Really though, you hit it a major point around the 4 min mark...the character needs to experience growth...just like Wasp, she was already stable, strong and we'll adjusted compared to Scotty...she is there to make him better. She enhances his character with her virtue. This subtlety seemed to be missed by many. Capt. Marvel where can she go? If she's "flawless" and has no romantic mobility what's the point. What seems to be frequently missed is that action scenes are the bonus for most men, we still want a story to follow. 
Never heard guys bash Widow, Underworlds, Wonder woman, Resident Evils, etc where there were strong lead female characters...folks like Brie have incorrectly identified a "problem". 

What I am saying is that I agree, it's not necessarily the "feminist" slant... it's the character and the story that were problematic and missed the mark.

author: @vincentmagius
text:
I think there were two "this why I'm a hero" moments in the movie.  Carol's wasn't shown, just told.  Where they talked about Mar-vel stealing the experimental plane and Carol said "if lives are on the line, I'm flying."  The other is with Rambeau, the friend.  She had the choice of staying with her daughter or fulfilling her dream by going on a dangerous mission to space.

Rambeau was there for all of five minutes and had a better character arc.

I think the "standing up" thing could have worked better if she failed more while with the Kree or backed down when confronted.  Then, when she gets her memories back and remembers who she is, her standing up would mean something.  She'd be the underdog or reluctant hero accepting their destiny.

author: @TJDK
text: Dude you are 100% right about what makes a hero a hero. This is why I often find myself looking at those early Marvel movies as worthy of being canonical they show us all their journey from average individual to the pantheon of greatness where the true heroes dwell. The first third of the Captain America flick is an amazing retelling of Steve Rogers' life and his beliefs. He refuses to back down from bullies despite the fact he was a little guy with no chance at winning. These acts of character, like despite the odds or outcome standing for what is right against a bully are as big a heroic symbol as the emblematic Captain America costume itself. Cap is the essence of truth justice and the American way to the old school fans. Without all of that Steve Rogers is just some super soldier fighting for his country. But when you add his morals into the mix he becomes this throwback to the purity and naivete of the 40s and 50s. Its his heart that got him chosen to begin with and that small realization is what codified Cap into the hero he is well was now that SJW Marvel writers turned him into a sleeper agent of Hydra which is why despite his best efforts can never defeat them.  SJW writers ruin everything IMHO

author: @Scorch1028
text: Captain Marvel had no ‚ÄúSocial Justice‚Äù themes in it.  It was pure Science Fiction/Fantasy.  1995 was one of the best years of my life, and the Captain Marvel soundtrack was delightfully nostalgic to me.  Women were as ‚Äúfully liberated‚Äù in 1995 as they are in 2019.  Hell! In 1983, Sallie Ride was the first American woman in space, and by early 1984 Geraldine Ferraro ran as Walter Mondale‚Äôs VP.  The glass ceiling was ‚Äúshattered‚Äù long before dial-up modems became popular.   In 1995, Hillary Clinton was ‚Äúrunning the White House‚Äù, which is why Little Rock, Arkansas has an airport called ‚ÄúBill and Hillary Clinton National Airport‚Äù!!!

author: @NPC1921
text: What pissed me off the most is the fact that not only was this movie mediocre, it was also completely tame and non-controversial. It wasn‚Äôt a political or radical feminist shitshow. It was just another Marvel movie. And still Brie Larson felt that white males wouldn‚Äôt like it on the sole fact that she‚Äôs a woman.

author: @jerrodkoland491
text: Finally a review that makes sense! I am in 100% agreement with this review. What is there to make you care about the character? With this story it doesn't matter if it is a female or a male character - the character has no soul - no moment to define them - nothing for us to relate to. I was worried that this would happen - I'm sorry it happened. Marvel really missed the mark with this one.

author: @filmandfirearms
text: I would say that the single best example of how to fit politics into a movie without ruining the movie is Casablanca. While we don't think about it in the modern day, that movie was absolutely made as a political allegory which people at the time would've noticed. Even though it was released in 1942, it was filmed before Operation Barbarossa, in June 1941, as evidenced by the fact that Renault mentions the Germans fighting on only one front. Notice how the characters are all allegories for the country they come from. Rick is an isolationist, and someone who doesn't care for the politics of the outside world and simply wants to rake in the benefits of it. Renault secretly hates the Germans, but puts on a very good face when dealing with them, and makes them seem like his friends. Laszlo is a man with nothing but the clothes on his back, not even a country to return to, and yet he never gives up fighting, no matter what the consequences might be. The whole point of the movie was to convince America to join the war, but they don't beat you over the head with it

author: @MarioRG719
text:
I saw the movie with 2 of my friends, and I remember laughing at the odd dialogue of the movie, mainly at the end. 

I remember laughing at the line Ronan says ‚Äúshe‚Äôs not a weapon, she‚Äôs a woman‚Äù 

And as someone not familiar with the comics, the dialogue used about the skrulls hounds weird. They‚Äôre ‚Äúterrorists‚Äù apparently, but if you ask the skrulls they‚Äôre refugees. 

But my favorite line is when Captain Marvel is talking to the Supreme Intelligence and their justification on what they did to the Skrulls (persecution based on lies) was ‚Äúwere just trying to protect our border!‚Äù 

Idk, it came off weird to me.

Edit - as someone pointed out, I misheard What Ronan said, or mistook how it was supposed to sound. I took it as him correcting him that she isn‚Äôt the weapon, but he probably meant that he‚Äôs gonna come after her because she‚Äôs basically what they were after originally or whatever. 

But the whole border parts are still a little odd to me.

replies.text:
Monstrosity thanks. After some digging yeah, that‚Äôs what he says. I must have misheard him or misunderstood what he was saying. 

Figures, if the line was as cliche as what I heard, more people would have been talking about it lol. 

Still think the lines about the border were funny tho.

author: @freedomanalysis2509
text:
*Pitch meeting.
Pitch guy: So what if the first female lead MCU film starred a very popular well developed fan favorite character like Black Widow or Scarlet Witch? And the-

Marvel producer: Let me stop you there. What if we made it starring this lady no one‚Äôs ever heard of, has practically has no personality, and doesn‚Äôt have any significance to the MCU? And we bait people into watching it by making them think it‚Äôs important to understanding Endgame despite the fact she‚Äôs barely in it and doesn‚Äôt do anything important to the plot.

Pitch guy: What? Okay but can her powers at least be interesting and unique?

Marvel Producer: She can fly, shoot energy beams, and is strong, fast, and durable. 

Pitch Guy: So like a discount Scarlet Witch and Captain America merge with the flying of Ironman?

Marvel Producer: Yes!

Pitch guy: Okay well we can still make this a fun movie for what it‚Äôs worth. Also we should make sure our movie is not political in any way. Even though Black Panther had nothing to do with Black Nationalism, so many people interpreted it that way from the trailers and the want among black racists to keep white people from seeing the movie. 

Marvel Producer: What if we made the movie completely Feminist even though most women don‚Äôt call themselves Feminists, and had the entire movie so Feminist it ruins it for you. 

Pitch Guy: ü§¶‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

author: @alexc4159
text: The thing that is telling is how much this reveals a lust for power coming from the left, how do you solve your problems? Good attributes, growth, humility, responsibility, understanding, and a desire and duty to good? No forget that rubish, the only thing on display is raw un earned power. it's all about might is the absolute right but only when we have it. when a guy on a motorcycle flirts with her the audience is supposed to see him as opressive, never mind the fact that in no way has he violated or tried to coerce her, never mind the movie failed to even indicate bad intentions, he is "oppressive". when she uses her power over him to actually subjugate him with force by threatening to break his arm to take from him what she pleases we are supposed to see this as an appropriate and reasonable response to him harmlessly flirting with her? Mild inconvenience to the wrong person from someone lower on the intersectional pecking order is oppression, use subjugation and actual oppression  in response is an equivalent, just, and right response to a mild unintended offence from someone arbitrarily born white and male...you know.....cos equality.

author: @hugh-johnfleming289
text:
Whenever I have been made to suffer these epic, millions wasted on the same empty story again, I think of the 100s of great stories out there collecting dust that could make another, say, 'French Connection' for a fraction of the budget.

The cheeseburgers will plunk their $12.50 down and sit in shoeboxes sucking 'blanc-mange' through a straw. Hollywood will find its gamblers again. Good cinema is not dead. The means to an end is far too available, cheap and simple. It is the audience that needs change. What this movie shows is the Coliseum is beginning to crumble. Thank God.

text: Can't say I really found myself caring about their attempts of a feminist messaged movie, but that is probably because I found the character to be so ridiculously bland I found myself concentrating more on the side characters then her.  Wonder Woman was interesting and had depth....this person was about as flat as a piece of paper...finds out her comrades were lying the whole time,  no reaction....what should be an emotional scene of her friend being concerned about whether or not she was talking to her friend or not just her body...no reaction. The cat showed more reaction then Captain Marvel. It was all ridiculously bland

author: @samuelwallace2782
text:
It was ok. She was overpowered but so is superman and I don't find either interesting. (I'll acknowledge that some people are hard to please: powerful woman=Mary sue, woman who overcomes literally any physical barrier=unrealistic, woman who outmarts men=sjw character.). Captain marvel was always going to be an unsatisfying movie because the character is essentially invincible.  
I have no problem with a movie with a female character who is better than men even if it's inexplicable (star wars) because it's a fantasy. I have a problem when a movie sells itself as smashing the patriarchy, and says anyone who disapproves is sexist. 
Even then my only real problem with captain marvel is people saying that it is the best. It was just ok, and that's ok. It's not the best marvel movie, and it's not the worst (that's thor 2). It just is.

author: @systematic101
text: The movie was SO boring. The character had 0 growth. She started with power and without ever over coming anything gains more power she already had. The reason characters like Iron Man, Hulk, Thor, and Black Widow do so well IS because they have faults and had to hit the bottom at some point. Tony was arrogant and almost died at the hands of his own creation. Then he had to over come the position of dying in a cave to save himself and then completely change his way. Thor was a similar story. Bruce had the problem of dealing with the Hulk and tried to kill himself when he was at the bottom. Then he came to terms with what he is and grew to control it. Black Window has a dark bloody past she always has hanging over her. Carol in the movie gets huge amount of power with pretty much 0 downside.

All the other heroes have problems they have to over come and no not problems like the makeup used by captain marvel. They got hurt and had to redeem themselves. Marvel does t have to redeem shit she just takes a thing off her neck and remembers her past....ooooooooo such a challenge. I dunno, the movie was wack of course, but I have a hard time seeing this as being pro-woman at all. Since the person in this film is not a woman but a mythological wizard character that doesn't exist anywhere in the observable universe.  

....Just saying.

author: @mnguardianfan7128
text:
"she's inherently right... because she's a woman"... That conclusion is ALL YOU that is not in the movie.

The message of the movie is about finding the confidence within yourself and that you are more powerful than you believe.... There is NO cavaet of 'Only if you are a woman'...  
This is a universal message of self empowerment, NOT limited to feminists and women.  Yes it obviously applies to women and yes the lead is a woman, but YOU are the one who is thinking it is purely a feminist message.

You repeatedly add 'because she's a woman'... That is all YOU... that is your bias showing through.

The whole 'you're too emotional' thing was about being honest with your feelings and not hide from them.  That applies to men just as well.  And goes to the self-empowerment theme.

Honest question. You said "it is established that Carol Danvers and her friend...who I will refer to as 'her friend' ".... Why did you say this? I honestly don't know what you are alluding to.

YOU are the one hung up on the cartoonish characture... in this case of an activist liberal 'SJW' Disney screenwriter.

You obviously when into this move looking for feminist elements for you to hate.  You never really gave this movie a chance.  You wanted to hate this movie because you hate SJWs SO much.  That comes across in this video loud and clear.

author: @deedlessdeity218
text:
Look at Mythra for a strong female character with bonkers powers and a real arc for it, her whole damn story. Yes, it's a video game, yes Xenoblade 2 has writing issues, doesn't change the fact she is prove that writing a technically overpowered female character (like any) is possible; and before you argue that she is not the lead character, look at the story from different angles. Many characters are very fleshed out, especially in the later released prestory. Looking at it like that, Mythra and Malos become the key main characters in this Jungian play.

Spoilers:
The thing with XC2, with all its errors, is that almost all its characters are written so strongly they can stand on their own. Jin is a fall from grace, consumed by nihilism after the loss of his love. Addam, who seems a too perfect and strong hero, a leader and ruler anyone would wish for, is revealed to be quite wary of his weak points and insecurities that he knows he cannot show as it would demoralize everyone. Rex is an inexperienced naive late teen with a kind heart, yet he knows little about the world and when it is better to retreat instead of keep charging recklessly headfirst against an ultimate force, devastated at losing the only father figure he's ever had in his life and only known for a brief few days who sacrificed himself for him and his friends before his eyes - still teaching him something all the while. Malos, the antagonist has depth too. He could have destroyed the world easily at any moment, including during the prestory. He has that power, just like Mythra. Yet his plans encompass more than that, he is not merely about destruction of everything.
Mythra herself, with her equally strong powers? She is afraid of them, a battle with the Jungian shadow, that permeates ever chapter in this story (an issue Nia shares with her). She kept herself short for Addam could not control her at first, but even then it was just a glimmer of her true capatbilities. When she lost control and destroyed more than just Malos, the grief and trauma was so strong she never wanted to touch those powers again and created a fake personality, a split in herself, if you will.
The reemergence came only in a dire moment to save a loved one - looking like a classic japanese Deus Ex Machina moment, yet knowing the story it makes perfect sense and still has limitations.
In effect, it turns out to be a battle between godlike powers in which all other characters are mere backdrop. Something to make the time worthwhile and interesting and give meaning: Life.
Eventually, Mythra learns to integrate her shadow thanks to her friends and loved ones and thereby gains the true power of herself which allows to overcome any obstacle together.

In end, even Mythra's lack of cooking skills would make for a greater character flaw than anything Captain Feminist Face has.
Something so frustrating to Mythra that her fake artificial personality was able to cook the most sublime of things.

Mythra's personality grows from a coldshouldered snobbish tsundere reckless with her powers, to a meek ever kind loving friend afraid of her powers, to someone truly integrated in the self at peace and balance with herself, ending in self-sacrifice for her friends and the world itself. With this arc no matter her powers, she is an interesting an lovable character.

Captain Marvel on the other hand? Never a change. Boring, bland, irrelevant. A true power fantasy. A feminist fetish story.

author: @freedomanalysis2509
text:
*Pitch meeting.
Pitch guy: So what if the first female lead MCU film starred a very popular well developed fan favorite character like Black Widow or Scarlet Witch? And the-

Marvel producer: Let me stop you there. What if we made it starring this lady no one‚Äôs ever heard of, has practically has no personality, and doesn‚Äôt have any significance to the MCU? And we bait people into watching it by making them think it‚Äôs important to understanding Endgame despite the fact she‚Äôs barely in it and doesn‚Äôt do anything important to the plot.

Pitch guy: What? Okay but can her powers at least be interesting and unique?

Marvel Producer: She can fly, shoot energy beams, and is strong, fast, and durable.  

Pitch Guy: So like a discount Scarlet Witch and Captain America merge with the flying of Ironman?

Marvel Producer: Yes!

Pitch guy: Okay well we can still make this a fun movie for what it‚Äôs worth. Also we should make sure our movie is not political in any way. Even though Black Panther had nothing to do with Black Nationalism, so many people interpreted it that way from the trailers and the want among black racists to keep white people from seeing the movie. 

Marvel Producer: What if we made the movie completely Feminist even though most women don‚Äôt call themselves Feminists, and had the entire movie so Feminist it ruins it for you.
